section.title: The Cargo Editor

listitem.para: Data Restrictions - unique name, no overlaps

section.para:
The Cargo Editor dialog allows various aspects of a cargo to be modified. The top part of the dialog
contains information about the entire cargo, with inputs as follows:

entry.para: The vessel the cargo is assigned to.

If this checkbox is unchecked, the optimiser is free to reallocate the cargo to a different vessel. If the checkbox is checked, the optimiser will ensure that the cargo is assigned to the specified vessel.

If this checkbox is checked, the optimiser is free to pair the specified load and discharge slots of this cargo with different loads and discharges, if it finds more commercially viable pairings. If the checkbox is unchecked, the optimiser will not consider reallocating the specified pairing.

section.title: Slot Editors
section.para: The bottom part of the Cargo dialog
contains editor panels for each slot (transaction) in the cargo, with the main inputs being:

entry.para: The slot’s unique name (typically a load name and cargo name should be the same).

If this checkbox is checked, the optimiser can construct a schedule which does not contain the specified load or discharge slot (if this is commercially viable). If the checkbox is checked, the optimiser will try to ensure that the specified transaction occurs in the generated schedule.
The port where the LNG is loaded or discharged.
The organisational entity which legally conducts the transaction. Overrides contract default.
If the checkboxes next to these inputs are checked, you can specify a minimum or maximum volume of LNG for the transaction. This can either be m³ or mmBtu. Overrides contract defaults.
This input allows you to make notes or comments regarding the slot.

section.para: The slot editor has various collapsible sections
which can be clicked to expand the section and edit the relevant slot details.

section.title: The Pricing Section
section.para: This section allows the pricing structure of the transaction to be specified, with inputs being:

entry.para: If the “Contract” checkbox is checked, you can determine the transaction price by choosing a particular contract, which will calculate price based on various factors.

If the “Expression” checkbox is checked, you can determine the price for this transaction directly, either as a given number of USD per mmBtu, or as a mathematical expression involving one or more industry indices. You must specify either a contract or a price expression.

If this checkbox is checked, you can specify a date on which the price for the transaction is based, which is different from the date the transaction actually occurs on. If the checkbox is unchecked, the date for calculating the price will be the actual date of the transaction.

This field allows you to specify a profit & loss term which is linked to the selected slot (whether it is used or not); the value may be either positive (profit) or negative (loss). This term will not affect the decisions made by the optimiser, but will be reflected in profit & loss reports.
This field allows you to specify a cost which must be paid if the slot is not used.

section.para: NOTE: This section will also include any contract-specific options for the slot.

section.title: The Window Section
section.para: The Window section specifies the time window during which the given transaction is permitted to occur, with inputs being:

entry.para: This gives the intended date for the transaction.
This input allows you to specify a time of day (according to the local timezone at the port) for the transaction. The default setting is 07:00.
This input allows you to specify the length of the available time window for the transaction (in hours). The default setting is 24hrs.
This input allows you to specify the maximum expected amount of time required to conduct the transaction (in hours). The default setting is 24hrs.

section.title: The Terms Section
section.para: The Terms section determines important conditions regarding the cargo. The exact inputs in this section depend on whether the slot is a load or discharge slot, and whether it is FOB or DES.

entry.para: If the “Arrive cold” input is set to “No”, then the vessel can be scheduled to arrive for its load with “warm” empty tanks. Overrides port.
The “Cargo CV” input specifies the calorific value (CV) of the LNG loaded at this slot in mmBtu per m3.

section.title: Terms Inputs for discharge slots only:

entry.para: The “Cargo Type” input may be set to “Shipped” to require that the LNG for this transaction must have been actually shipped from another port, or set to “Not Shipped” to require that the LNG must be bought and sold at the same port (e.g. in a FOB-FOB or DES-DES deal). The default setting is “Any”, which allows the sale to be paired with any purchase.
Min CV Value / Max CV Value
The “Min CV Value” and “Max CV Value” inputs allow minimum and maximum permissible calorific values (CV) in mmBtu per m3 to be associated with a discharge slot.

section.title: Terms Inputs for all slots:
section.para: A particular LNG load may have legal or practical restrictions on which port the LNG may be shipped to, which contracts it can be sold under, and which vessels can carry it. The same considerations may hold vice versa for discharges. These inputs determine those restrictions:

entry.para: The “Restricted Ports” input specifies a list of ports which the reciprocal transaction may not occur at (or, if “Restricted Lists Are Permissive” is set to “Yes”, it must occur at one of them).

The “Restricted Contracts” input specifies a list of contracts which the reciprocal transaction may not occur under (or, if “Restricted Lists Are Permissive” is set to “Yes”, it must occur under one of them).
If the “Allowed Vessels” input is set, it specifies a list of the vessels which can load (or discharge) at this slot. If it is left blank, any vessel is permitted.

section.para: Note: These override the contract defaults. If one value is overridden, then all three are deemed to override the contract.

section.title: Terms Inputs for DES purchases and FOB sales only:

entry.para: These transactions are not part of shipped cargoes, so the cargo itself is not assigned a vessel. The “Assignment” input determines which vessel is nominated for the transaction.

A non divertible slot is defined based upon it’s transfer point. For a DES purchase, this is the port and date where ownership is taken. If it is divertible then the some modelling of the third party shipping is involved (using the nominated vessel assignment). For a divertible DES purchase, the load port and estimated load date is specified. Divertible DES purchases also have a shipping days limit defining the maximum permitted round trip time for slot pairings.

section.title: Terms Inputs for DES purchases only:

entry.para: The “Sales Delivery Type” input may be set to “Shipped” to require that the LNG for this transaction must have been actually shipped from another port, or set to “Not Shipped” to require that the LNG must be bought and sold at the same port (e.g. in a FOB-FOB or DES-DES deal). The default setting is “Any”, which allows the sale to be paired with any purchase.
The name of the vessel class.
A list of ports which vessels of this class cannot use.
The type of base fuel used by vessels of this class.
The LNG tank volume in m3 for vessels of this class.
The percentage of the LNG tank volume which can actually be filled with LNG.
The minimum and maximum travel speed of the vessel in knots.
The minimum remaining quantity of LNG required to keep the vessel operational at the end of a voyage if LNG is on board.
The amount of time in hours that the vessel can operate with empty LNG tanks before requiring a cooldown.
The amount of excess LNG required to cool the tanks when they are warm.
Information on time and fuel consumption used to travel canals or other unusual routes.
The amount of base fuel used to keep a vessel operational on a pure LNG boiloff trip.

section.title: Laden / Ballast Attributes
section.para: These panels allow you to edit the details for the vessel class’s fuel consumption when the vessel is on a laden (carrying LNG cargo in its tanks) or ballast (travelling without cargo) voyage.

entry.para: The amount of LNG boiled off during a laden / ballast voyage
The amount of LNG boiled off while idling laden / unladen (ballast).
The amount of base fuel consumed while idling laden / unladen (ballast).
The amount of base fuel consumed while being actively processed at a port under laden / ballast conditions.
The typical voyage speed for a vessel when laden / unladen (ballast).
The ports linked to the contract (i.e. load port for purchase contracts, discharge ports for sales contracts). Can be left blank
A preferred, or default, port for the contract (used when creating new slots).
Default slot minimum and maximum transfer volume in m3.
Free text field to user notes on the contract.
Whether this contract is just for FOB or DES transactions or both. For purchase contracts this means FOB Purchase or DES Purchase. For sales contracts this means DES Sales or FOB Sales.
Fixed fee for not using a slot linked to this contract.
(Purchase Only) Contract purchase CV if different to CV defined on the load port.
Flips restrictions from blacklisted contracts and ports to whitelisted contracts and ports.
List of contracts which cannot be linked to this contract (or if restrictions are permissive then this is the list of contracts which can only be linked to this one).
List of ports which cannot be linked to this contract (or if restrictions are permissive then this is the list of ports which can only be linked to this one).
(Sales Only) Only link to purchases with a CV value within this range.
(Sales Only) Shipped means only link to FOB Purchases, Non Shipped means only link to DES Purchases.
(Purchase Only) Shipped means only link to DES Sales, Non Shipped means only link to FOB Sales.
